title: How to Use a Hyphenated Last Name

steps.title: Have your proof ready.
steps.content: Have your proof ready. When changing your name on your Social Security card, you need to have proof of your new name. Because you are likely changing your name because of marriage, the best document is a marriage license that shows your new name. [1] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source You'll also need proof of identity, such as a state-issued ID or driver's license or a passport. In some cases, other forms of ID can be substituted, such as an employee or school identification card or a military identification card. [2] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source If you don't change your name with Social Security, it can affect government services. For instance, the IRS won't recognize your hyphenated name if it's not the one that's associated with your Social Security Number.

steps.title: Obtain the form.
steps.content: Obtain the form. You can print out the form online. You can also get the form at your local Social Security office. Either way, you must turn the form in physically in person or by mail, so you must have a physical copy. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Fill in the form.
steps.content: Fill in the form. You will need to fill in some basic biographical information. For instance, you'll need to include your address, Social Security Number, and place of birth. Nonetheless, the form is fairly short and shouldn't take you very long to complete. [4] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source Be sure to read the instructions ahead of time. For instance, you only need both parents' Social Security Numbers if you are applying for a brand new card for someone under 18. In this case, then, you don't need both parents' Social Security Numbers, but those are still blanks on the forms. [5] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source

steps.title: Submit your form.
steps.content: Submit your form. You can take the form to your local Social Security office. You can also mail it in if you prefer. [6] X Research source To find your local office, look in the phone book, or use the Social Security Administration's locator to find your nearest office. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Wait for your new card.
steps.content: Wait for your new card. Your card should arrive by mail. As long as you filed all the necessary documents, it should be at your house in about a week and a half. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Change your driver's license.
steps.content: Change your driver's license. Even though your name is similar to your old name, you need to change it on your driver's license. How you change it depends on your state. Usually, you'll have to change your license in person. [9] X Research source Before going to your local department of motor vehicles, check online or call to see what you'll need. Usually, you'll need to fill out a form for renewal or a name change. The name of the form will vary by state. You'll also be asked to pay a fee. [10] X Research source Most of the time, you won't need your Social Security card first. You will need your old driver's license and proof that you changed your name, which is your marriage license in most states. [11] X Research source You'll also need to change the information on your car's registration and title. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Change all legal documents.
steps.content: Change all legal documents. When you change your last name, that means you need to make all your legal documents match. For instance, you need to change your name on your insurance and at your bank. All of your bills need to have your new name. Have your marriage license ready so you can show that you changed your name. Some places may require your new Social Security card. Try to think of all your bills, not just the ones you pay monthly. For instance, you may forget to change your name on your toll pass if it's not coming out monthly. Also, remember to change your name at places like your doctor's office, as they will be looking for your insurance under your old name if you don't.

steps.title: Think about social media.
steps.content: Think about social media. Another issue you need to think about is social media. You can change your name as you see fit. You're not required legally to do so, but you can change your name on major social media platforms and blogs. However, if you have a specific URL (website address), changing that will be more difficult and time-consuming than just changing your name on the account. On some social media platforms, you may not be able to change it. Some websites do have limits on how often you can change your name, so make sure you are ready to change it when you do.

steps.title: Decide which name you want to use professionally.
steps.content: Decide which name you want to use professionally. If you have been known under a certain name professionally, you can still keep using that name as long as your legal documents are under your legal name. However, you can also switch over to your new hyphenated name. [13] X Research source Some women keep using their maiden name because they are well-known in their community under that name. For instance, if you're a local author or real estate agent, it may be better to keep using your maiden name. [14] X Research source If you've gotten married, though, and many people know about your marriage, you should clarify how you want to be known from now on. Many people will assume you're taking your husband's name solely. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Clarify you have a hyphenated name.
steps.content: Clarify you have a hyphenated name. When making appointments or reservations, it's important to clarify you have a hyphenated last name to make it easier for the other person. If you don't, the other person may try to mash your name into some sort of bizarre hybrid, plus you're giving them a heads up about the punctuation. For example, you could say, "Are you ready for my last name? It's hyphenated. It's Smith-hyphen-Jones."

steps.title: Be prepared for other problems.
steps.content: Be prepared for other problems. For instance, hyphenated names can cause issues with computer systems sometimes, which may not recognize the hyphen in a name field or may not know how to classify the name properly. [16] X Research source Other times, forms are too short to fit your name, or you may find that an email address has a character limit shorter than your hyphenated name. Nonetheless, hyphenated names do have some pluses. For instance, hyphenating usually creates a unique name, meaning no one else is likely to have your first and last name combination. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Discuss the options.
steps.content: Discuss the options. When naming your kids, you do have several options. You can give them either one of the parent's original surnames. You can also give them the hyphenated name. Some parents form hybrid names, so the kid isn't stuck with a hyphenated name. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Giving your child either your surname or your spouse's is a good option if one of you feels more strongly about carrying on your family's name.
steps.content: Giving your child either your surname or your spouse's is a good option if one of you feels more strongly about carrying on your family's name. [19] X Research source For instance, it can also create identity issues, as your kids' names are not technically the same as your name if you have a hyphenated name.

steps.title: Consider identity.
steps.content: Consider identity. While younger kids may not have a problem with having different last names from one of their parents, as kids get a little older and go to school, they may start making comparisons with other kids. It can be confusing to them to have a name that is not the same. [20] X Research source They may also get questions from other kids about their last name, and why it's not the same as one parent or the other. Names connect families, and having the same name can show kids that they belong.

steps.title: Understand why hyphens can cause problems.
steps.content: Understand why hyphens can cause problems. Sometimes, hyphenated names present their own set of problems for kids. For one, many kids have trouble learning to spell out longer names when they're first learning to write. [21] X Research source Hyphenation can also cause administrative issues since some places are unsure whether to file under the first surname or the second surname. [22] X Research source It can also cause future problems if the kid decides he or she wants to hyphenate last names later, as that adds a third surname to the mix.
